The band begins at ten to six
“Ten to six” is another Lennon invention – the poster just mentions “Tuesday evening”.
The Hendersons will all be there

“The Hendersons” are not actually mentioned on John Lennon’s circus poster, but “J. (John) Henderson” is. He was “a wire-walker, equestrian, trampoline artist, and clown.” Though the poster only mentioned John, he also performed with his wife Agnes, which makes it even stranger that The Beatles made it plural. They traveled and performed throughout Russia and Europe during the 1840s and 1850s.
[Instrumental Break]

After the last line of the second verse, the song breaks into a short instrumental section that paints a clear picture of a circus atmosphere. According to The Beatles Bible website, producer George Martin spliced together multiple recordings of fairground organs and calliopes with tape loops—along with several other unique instruments—to create an 18th century circus sound full of psychedelic noises and surreal sounds.
A splendid time is guaranteed for all

This is referencing how the circus is intended as a fun or “splendid” event / attraction that is meant to delight and excite you.

This may also be a reference to the back cover of the album, as it states: “This is a stereo recording. A splendid time is guaranteed for all.”



The back of the cover album could also just be a reference to the song itself, instead of vice versa.
And of course Henry The Horse dances the waltz!

“Henry The Horse” was mistaken by the BBC for a reference to the drug Heroin. Lennon adamantly denied that this had anything to do with a drug reference:

“Everything in the song is from that poster, except the horse wasn’t called Henry. Now, there were all kinds of stories about Henry the Horse being heroin. I had never seen heroin in that period. No, it’s all just from that poster.”

Perhaps John chose the name Henry because of the Henderson’s manager Henry Hengler. Not to mention the childlike alliteration that works so very well with the song.
[Verse 3]

John Lennon himself said he wanted to “Smell the sawdust” in reference to how he wanted the carnivalesque nature of this song to be.

George Martin showed that he completely understood what John was envisioning and developed some pretty neat soundscape improvisation for the middle 8 bars and ending of the song.

“I knew we needed a backwash, a general mush of sound, like if you go to a fairground, shut your eyes and listen: rifle shots, hurdy-gurdy noises, people shouting and – way n the distance – just a tremendous chaotic sound. So I got hold of old calliope tapes, playing Stars And Stripes Forever and other Sousa marches, chopped the tapes up into small sections and had Geoff Emerick throw them up in the air, re-assembling them at random.”
[Verse 1]

The song was usually accredited to John Lennon because of what he said in a 1970 interview:

“I wrote that as a pure poetic job, to write a song sitting there. I had to write because it was time to write. And I had to write it quick because otherwise I wouldn’t have been on the album. So I had to knock off a few songs. I knocked off A Day In The Life, or my section of it, and whatever we were talking about, Mr Kite, or something like that. I was very paranoid in those days, I could hardly move.”

But Paul McCartney sets us straight on what really happened in a 2013 interview:

 “I read, occasionally, people say, ‘Oh, John wrote that one.’ I say, ‘Wait a minute, what was that afternoon I spent with him, then, looking at this poster?’ He happened to have a poster in his living room at home. I was out at his house, and we just got this idea, because the poster said ‘Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite’ – and then we put in, you know, ‘there will be a show tonight,’ and then it was like, ‘of course,’…The song just wrote itself. So, yeah, I was happy to kind of reclaim it as partially mine.”

And, they do in fact have trampolines.



The poster reads:

Mr. HENDERSON will,
for the first time in Rochdale,
introduce his extraordinary
TRAMPOLINE LEAPS
AND
SOMERSETS!
Ten somersets he’ll undertake on solid ground

The word ‘somerset’ was also used in Victorian England to describe what today we call a somersault.



Even the Beatles didn’t know what a ‘somerset’ was before writing this song, as McCartney recalls when he and John were translating the poster into a song:

“We said, ‘What was ‘somersets’? It must have been an old-fashioned way of saying somersaults.’ The song just wrote itself.”
